data.question: What is the coordination environment of silver(I) in the synthesized porous coordination polymer?
data.answer: Silver(I) in the synthesized porous coordination polymer has a linear coordination environment.

data.question: How does the synthesized [Ag2(Me4bpz)] framework accommodate guest molecules of different sizes?
data.answer: The synthesized [Ag2(Me4bpz)] framework accommodates guest molecules of different sizes by undergoing structural transformations, which include expanding some cavities and shrinking others simultaneously.

data.question: What role do the {Ag3(pz)3} subunits play in the structure of the synthesized porous coordination polymer?
data.answer: The {Ag3(pz)3} subunits act as three-connected nodes in the structure of the synthesized porous coordination polymer.

data.question: What is the significance of the guest-responsive pores in flexible porous coordination polymers?
data.answer: The guest-responsive pores in flexible porous coordination polymers provide strong confinement effects for specific guest molecules by shrinking or expanding in different guest-inclusion states.

data.question: How does the adsorption behavior of CO2 and N2 gases confirm the porosity of the synthesized material?
data.answer: The abrupt sorption at low relative pressure (Type I profile) in the adsorption isotherms of CO2 and N2 confirms the presence of uniform micropores in the synthesized material.

data.question: What is the effect of guest molecule size on the structural transformation of the synthesized porous coordination polymer?
data.answer: Larger guest molecules necessitate a structural transformation of the synthesized porous coordination polymer to accommodate them, due to the size difference between the pore aperture and the guest molecules.

data.question: What is the process to synthesize the [Ag2(Me4bpz)]·guest compound?
data.answer: The [Ag2(Me4bpz)]·guest compound is synthesized by reacting a silver–ammonia solution with an ethanol solution of H2Me4bpz, resulting in colorless polyhedral crystals.

data.question: How does the structure of the synthesized material change upon guest molecule removal?
data.answer: Upon guest molecule removal, the structure of the synthesized material undergoes a single-crystal to single-crystal (SCSC) transformation, indicating thermal stability of the host framework.

data.question: What happens to the synthesized material when exposed to benzene and toluene vapors?
data.answer: When exposed to benzene and toluene vapors, the synthesized material undergoes a SCSC transformation to a new crystal phase, accommodating the guest molecules with decreased symmetry and varied cavity shapes.

data.question: How are guest molecules accommodated in the cavities of the synthesized material?
data.answer: Guest molecules are accommodated in the cavities of the synthesized material through cooperative movement of the host framework, which expands some cavities and shrinks others to fit as many guest molecules as possible.

data.question: What is the role of Ag···p interactions in the inclusion of guest molecules?
data.answer: Ag···p interactions play a significant role in the inclusion of guest molecules by confining each guest molecule with three or six silver centers, indicating strong host–guest interactions.

data.question: Can the original phase of the synthesized material be recovered after guest inclusion?
data.answer: Yes, the original phase of the synthesized material can be recovered by heating the single crystal of the guest-included compound at 90–110 8C, demonstrating reversible SCSC transformations.
